ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I definitely learned a lot more about calculus than I had learn in high school.
Elementary calculus us helpful but Mr. Hart ensures that even those who have limited math knowledge can understand the subject matter.
Mathematical and analytical reasoning, broad STEM knowledge
I learnt and reviewed a lot of content done in highschool calc that I needed to brush up on like integration and differentiation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - Mr. Hart, small group teaching, many opportunities to practice, easily reviewable with Ximera, Mr. Hart's worksheets, encouragement of class collaboration, opens the door to the econ major and many others. 
Weaknesses - the tests were a little hard, the p-sets take too long and having one during reading week is unfair, clearly your instructor has a significant effect on your success... many people not in Mr. Hart's section complained extensively and, when attending review sessions hosted by other professors, it is clear that your instruction really matters!

For strengths, I enjoyed being challenged by the course content as this was a field that I was previously unfamiliar with. I genuinely enjoyed all the learning I did and think it will have useful applications in basically any STEM subject I delve in later on. For weaknesses, the course being labelled as an intro was misleading as majority of people had previous calculus knowledge which inflated the curves. The workload was so much that the subject became parasitizing. The problem sets were impossibly hard compared to what we were taught in class and basically impossible to complete without going to either office hours or tutor hours.

I loved the ximeras as they are a brilliant way to supplement and re-enforce topics learnt in class especially when you dont understand them initially. I think the p-sets do get repetitive and can be draining sometimes

The strengths of the course was the Ximera, which presented lecture material in a digestible way. The weakness of the course was the difficulty of exams and problem sets, which oftentimes did not reflect course material adequately.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: With Mr. Hart, yes! You'll likely have to take it and its really not that bad in terms of difficulty and workload. Also, great class dynamic and some fun classes!

I would recommend this to someone who has taken calc before. If not, math 110 and 111 would be way better. Moreover, I would not recommend this to someone taking 5 credits as the workload is not easy to deal with and math requires a lot of attention.
I believe if you wanna go further in math or you have to take a QR its definitely a neccessity.
If a student is simply looking to get a QR credit, this is not the right course. However, to learn calculus for a STEM major, this course is recommended and necessary.
